Problem:
Consider the integral transformation \\( T[f](s) = \\int_0^\\infty e^{-st} f(t) dt \\), where \\( f(t) = e^{At} \\) and A is a matrix. We analyze the causal effect of a matrix intervention \\( B \\) on function \\( f(t) = e^{(A+B)t} \\) and its corresponding transformed function over time.

If an intervention applies a new matrix C at time \\( t_1 \\), so the function changes to \\( f(t) = e^{(A+C)t} \\), will the resulting transform \\( T[f](s) \\) at T > t_1 be independent of the initial matrices A and B?
Explanation: The intervention leads to a new function \\( f(t) = e^{(A+C)t} \\), and the resulting transformation \\( T[f](s) \\) will contain the effects of C along with the initial matrix A. The transformation's result at any time T > t_1 is influenced by both A and C, and potentially B if it affects conditions preceding t_1.

causal_map_integration: The matrix A causes the function f(t), the matrix B also causes the function f(t), and the matrix C causes the function f(t) when applied at time t_1. The function f(t) influences the transformed function T[f](s). The combination of matrices A and B influences f(t), as does the combination of matrices A and C. The time point t_1 determines the influence of matrix C on f(t), and the transformed function T[f](s) is determined for times greater than t_1.
